title: 103_hr334
content: The "Lumbee Recognition Act" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. The Act of June 7, 1956 preamble is amended to recognize the Lumbee Indians of North Carolina as descendants of coastal tribes, recognized by the state since 1885, seeking federal recognition since 1888, and entitled to federal recognition. The Lumbee Indians are entitled to Federal recognition as an Indian tribe and the benefits that come with it. Federal recognition is extended to the Lumbee Tribe of Cheraw Indians of North Carolina, allowing them to receive benefits and protections under US laws. Other Indian groups in the area can petition for acknowledgment of tribal existence. Federal recognition is granted to the Lumbee Tribe of Cheraw Indians of North Carolina, enabling them to access benefits and protections under US laws. Other Indian groups in the region can also seek acknowledgment of their tribal existence. The Lumbee Tribe of Cheraw Indians of North Carolina and its members are eligible for services and benefits provided to federally recognized Indians, with the exception that funds must be appropriated first. Members residing in specific counties are considered to be near an Indian reservation. The Secretary of the Interior and Health and Human Services will work with the tribe to determine needs and budget for eligible services after verifying the tribal roll. The Lumbee Tribe of Cheraw Indians of North Carolina is authorized to plan, conduct, consolidate, and administer programs and services under specific Acts, with an annual funding agreement among the tribe, the Secretary of the Interior, and the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Services and functions to be provided will be specified in the agreement. The Lumbee Tribe of Cheraw Indians of North Carolina is authorized to reallocate funds and modify budget allocations within a fiscal year. The Secretary of the Interior is responsible for auditing the tribe's expenditures. This authority is in place of the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. The tribe's sovereign immunity and trust responsibilities with the United States are not affected by this subsection. The Lumbee Tribe of Cheraw Indians of North Carolina has the authority to reallocate funds and modify budget allocations within a fiscal year, with the Secretary of the Interior responsible for auditing expenditures. This authority is granted in place of the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act, and does not affect the tribe's sovereign immunity or trust responsibilities with the United States. The Lumbee Tribe of Cheraw Indians of North Carolina must organize and adopt a constitution and bylaws consistent with the Act. The Secretary of the Interior will assist in this process, including conducting elections. Until a constitution is adopted, tribal membership will be based on the current membership roll, subject to review by the Secretary. Before adopting a constitution, the Lumbee Tribe of Cheraw Indians in North Carolina must open the tribal roll for a 180-day period to allow enrollment of individuals from other Indian groups or tribes in Robeson or adjoining counties. The tribe must advertise the enrollment criteria and deadline in newspapers. The Lumbee Tribe of Cheraw Indians in North Carolina must verify compliance with membership criteria stated in their petition for federal acknowledgment within a 12-month period after closing the tribal roll. The Lumbee Tribe of Cheraw Indians in North Carolina must verify compliance with membership criteria within a 12-month period after closing the tribal roll, including jurisdiction. The State of North Carolina has jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on lands owned by the Lumbee Tribe of Cheraw Indians. The Secretary of the Interior can accept transfers of jurisdiction from the state to the United States. The Lumbee Tribe of Cheraw Indians in North Carolina may transfer jurisdiction to the United States, with a two-year waiting period. This transfer does not affect the Indian Child Welfare Act. The Lumbee Tribe is subject to certain Acts regarding lands in Robeson and adjoining counties. The Lumbee Tribe of Cheraw Indians in North Carolina may transfer jurisdiction to the United States with a two-year waiting period. Funds are authorized to be appropriated for the tribe's expenditures under this Act, with proposals to be submitted to specific committees prior to any expenditure. The Act was passed by the House of Representatives on October 28, 1993.
